Blockchain in 2025: Trends, Challenges, and Future Prospects
Blockchain technology has evolved significantly over the past decade, expanding beyond cryptocurrencies into various industries, including finance, healthcare, supply chain, and governance.

Blockchain technology has evolved significantly over the past decade, expanding beyond cryptocurrencies into various industries, including finance, healthcare, supply chain, and governance. As we step into 2025, new developments and innovations continue to shape the blockchain landscape. This article explores key trends, challenges, and future prospects of blockchain technology.

## Key Trends in Blockchain

### 1. Enterprise Blockchain Adoption

Businesses are increasingly integrating blockchain for enhanced security, transparency, and efficiency. Companies in sectors such as finance, logistics, and healthcare leverage blockchain to streamline operations and secure transactions. Major firms like IBM and Microsoft continue to develop blockchain-based enterprise solutions ([source](https://www.ibm.com/topics/what-is-blockchain)).

### 2. Growth of Decentralized Finance (DeFi)

DeFi platforms continue to disrupt traditional finance by offering decentralized lending, borrowing, and trading without intermediaries. Protocols such as Uniswap and Aave provide users with greater financial control and accessibility ([source](https://decrypt.co/resources/what-is-defi)).

### 3. Integration of AI and Blockchain

The convergence of AI and blockchain enhances automation, security, and efficiency. AI-driven smart contracts enable real-time data analysis, fraud detection, and autonomous decision-making. This synergy fosters advancements in predictive analytics and decentralized applications ([source](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/2023/05/12/how-ai-and-blockchain-are-reshaping-business/)).

### 4. Enhanced Scalability Solutions

Scalability has been a persistent challenge for blockchain networks. Layer 2 solutions like Optimistic Rollups and zk-Rollups significantly improve transaction speeds and reduce costs, making blockchain more viable for mass adoption ([source](https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/scaling/)).

### 5. Regulatory Developments and Compliance

Governments worldwide are working towards regulatory clarity for blockchain and cryptocurrencies. Compliance frameworks such as MiCA in the EU and updated SEC guidelines in the US aim to provide investor protection while fostering innovation ([source](https://www.coindesk.com/policy/2024/01/12/how-europe-is-leading-the-way-in-crypto-regulation)).

## Challenges in Blockchain Adoption

### 1. Energy Consumption and Sustainability

While Proof-of-Stake (PoS) and other energy-efficient mechanisms reduce blockchainâ€™s carbon footprint, mining-intensive Proof-of-Work (PoW) networks still face criticism for high energy consumption.

### 2. Security Concerns and Smart Contract Vulnerabilities

Hacks and exploits in smart contracts remain a major challenge. Secure coding practices, audits, and insurance mechanisms are critical for reducing vulnerabilities.

### 3. User Experience and Adoption Barriers

Complexity in using blockchain-based applications can hinder mass adoption. Improving user interfaces, simplifying wallets, and offering better customer support are essential for mainstream acceptance.

## Future Prospects of Blockchain

### 1. Cross-Chain Interoperability

The future of blockchain lies in seamless interoperability between different networks. Solutions like Polkadot and Cosmos aim to create a connected blockchain ecosystem.

### 2. Decentralized Identity and Web3 Evolution

Self-sovereign identity (SSI) and Web3 applications empower users with greater control over their personal data and online interactions.

### 3. Tokenization of Real-World Assets

Real estate, stocks, and commodities are increasingly being tokenized on blockchain, enabling fractional ownership and liquidity in traditionally illiquid markets.

## Conclusion

Blockchain technology continues to evolve, offering new opportunities and overcoming existing challenges. With advancements in scalability, security, and regulatory clarity, blockchain is poised to play a crucial role in the digital economy of 2025 and beyond.

Blockchain technology continues to evolve, offering new opportunities and overcoming existing challenges. With advancements in scalability, security, and regulatory clarity, blockchain is poised to play a crucial role in the digital economy of 2025 and beyond.

```js {1,3-4} showLineNumbers /AnchorLink/
import Link from "next/link";

interface AnchorLinkProps {
  href: string;
  children: string;
  target?: "_blank" | "_parent" | "_self" | "_top";
}

const AnchorLink = ({ href, children, target }: AnchorLinkProps) => {
  return (
    <Link
      href={href}
      target={target}
      className="text-secondary-200 hover:text-accent font-medium transition-colors duration-300 ease-in-out"
    >
      {children}
    </Link>
  );
};

export default Anchor;
export default AnchorLink;
```

Programming Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Ipsa vitae, incidunt, asperiores autem laboriosam, eaque tempore facilis odio suscipit pariatur nihil ipsum consectetur odit perferendis. Modi ea mollitia nam quaerat BERAK.
This post shares my journey on creating this blog. I talk about what's behind and how everything fits together and the reason I choose certain tech stacks over another.

It's been years since I typed my first line of code. I don't remember exactly what made me interested in learning to code, but I remember for sure the feeling when the first time I saw the output â€” `"Hello, World!"` â€” of my first line of code. As far as I remember, I wrote my first line of code in PHP. PHP was very popular because, as someone with limited knowledge on programming back then, I had heard of it once or twice before actually learning it myself. When I typed "Which programming language should I learn" into Google, PHP definitely came up as one of them, and it showed how popular this programming language was. And then Python started to came up on my radar. I switched to Python because I found its syntax easier, making it a beginner-friendly programming language. These two programming languages had their own purposes. That's why I switched back to PHP later, as I became curious about how websites are made. All I knew was that if you want to build a website, you need to know about HTML, CSS, and two different programming languages â€” JavaScript for the frontend and PHP for the backend. It was a lot of things to learn and remember, but I enjoyed the process. The more learned, the more knowledge I gained about programming. I started to know that JavaScript can actually be used to write the backend of a website. This became possible because of something called Node.Js. It was very cool to me because you don't need an extra programming language to build a website. Fewer languages mean fewer things to remember mean more enjoyable learning process. Up until now, I've been focusing my learning on JavaScript and its ecosystem. The goal from start was clear: I want to built my own blog from scratch first someday. That day has finally come. Okay, enough talking about my learning story â€” let's move to the main question: how did I build this blog? ## Content Management This was the most explorative and confusing part of my blog. My blog is just a [NextJS](https://nextjs.org/) application at its core. I write my content in MDX and push it a Github repository to post it. No database is involved to store the content â€” just static mdx files. MDX is cool, but the problem is there are no actual columns to fill as seen in CMS like WordPress. There are no columns for metadata like title, excerpt, and published date in MDX. Instead, MDX uses something called frontmatter to write metadata. Maybe you might wonder how that could be a problem. Well, it's not really a problem because frontmatter is actually great. But since it's just a key-value pair, we are very likely to produce unexpected output just because due typos when writing the keys. To handle this, I used something called [Content Collections](https://mdxjs.com "Go to Content Collections official website"). With Content Collections, my content is transformed into type-safe data collections, and it also handles the parsing and fetching process. Before the content is transformed into type-safe data, it's validated first to ensure accuracy. We can also preprocess our data before we using it in our app. Since I use TypeScript to build this blog, having type-safe content is excellent! Content Collections seemed is a good solution. Integration with NextJS was seamless, and I didn't encounter any problems initially. But something happened when I was almost finished building this blog. Unlike basic markdown, MDX allows me to use JSX in my markdown content. All I needed to do was import the JSX components in my markdown content, similar to importing a JSX component into a route page. The importing syntax look like this: ```mdx import DestinationCards from "@/components/DestinationCards"; # Top destination in Japan ``` Strangely, when using Content-Collections, my JSX components wouldn't render when I'm imported them into my markdown content. It produced an error. I don't know why this happened. Maybe there was something missing in my code. I tried to find it back and forth but still couldn't figure it out. This process was very time consuming. I litteraly spent a couple of days trying fix this error, but nothing worked. Content Collections is still in the early stages of development, so maybe it wasn't me. Or maybe it was just a skill issue (this one is more likely ðŸ˜­). I decided to move on. Astro instatntly came to mind when I decided to replace Content Collections because Astro has built-in type-safe content management feature. But I would need to rewrite a lot of my code to intergated it since it wasn't a React framework. Yes, I could use React in Astro to write JSX components, so I wouldn't need to rewrite them in Astro's syntax. But there was no point in using React in Astro if Astro itself is worked just fine. I needed a better replacement. It didn't take me long to find Velite. This was a perfect replacement for me because it's very similar to Content Collections but better. Both use [zod](https://zod.dev/) for schema validation, but Velite has [extended schemas](https://velite.js.org/guide/velite-schemas) that help a lot when building content models. With Velite, I only needed to make slight adjustments to make everything work. The error was solved, and I could finally use my JSX components in my markdown content. Yeay! ## Styling for User Interface When it comes to styling, I used Tailwind CSS. I have known Tailwind for a couple of years. I've been having a great time with Tailwind. Tailwind is a utility-first CSS framework. It allows developers to create great user interfaces by applying utility classes directly in HTML. With Tailwind, we can create beautiful user interface without ever leaving our HTML files (or tsx files in my case). The utility classes look like this: ```html

Welcome!

``` The html above will produce a heading with bold white text with 24px bottom margin. Since you only need to write utility classes in your html, Tailwind CSS is highly customizable. You can also create your own custom classes in Tailwind. Its customizability and ease of use enough to justify why I chose Tailwind for this blog. But I know Tailwind is not for everyone. Some people might not have a good development experience with it, and I can see why. Tailwind class can become very long and start to clutter your html files, making them less readable. And yes, it happens to me too. But I'm okay with it since I'm the one who is reading my own code. I also use the prettier-plugin-tailwindcss to sort the classes. With that prettier plugin, reading tailwind-classes-cluttered html files becomes even easier. ## Syntax Highlighting Shiki is perhaps one of the best when it comes to syntax Highlighter. Unfortunately, Shiki doesn't provide official Integration for NextJS yet. So instead of using Shiki directly in my blog, I used something called [rehype-pretty-code](https://rehype-pretty.pages.dev/). Rehype-pretty-code is basically a [rehype](https://github.com/rehypejs/rehype) plugin version of Shiki because it's based on Shiki. With rehype-pretty-code, integrating Shiki syntax highlighter with NextJS is much easier. I just needed to import it into my Velite config file as a plugin, choose a theme, and let it handle the rest. ```ts import { defineConfig } from "velite"; import rehypePrettyCode from "rehype-pretty-code"; import { transformerNotationDiff } from "@shikijs/transformers"; const highlighterTheme = JSON.parse( fs.readFileSync("./highlighter-theme.json", "utf-8"), ); export default defineConfig({ root: "content", output: { data: ".velite", }, collections: { blogs, programmings, movies, }, mdx: { rehypePlugins: [ rehypeSlug, rehypeAutolinkHeadings, [ rehypePrettyCode, { theme: await highlighterTheme, }, ], ], remarkPlugins: [remarkGfm, remarkToc], }, }); ``` ## Movie Review Section If you go to the [movie review](https://mfaisal.xyz/movies) section, besides my take on the movie, you'll also see metadata the like title, release year, genres, director, cast, and overview of the movie. I could get this kind of data manually by visiting [IMDb](https://www.imdb.com/), copying the data that I need, and pasting it into my content. But that's a lot of work. It would be much more convenient if it were done automatically through an API. Unfortunately, as far as I know, IMDB doesn't a provide free API. They offer an API through something called [AWS Data Exchange](https://aws.amazon.com/marketplace/seller-profile?id=0af153a3-339f-48c2-8b42-3b9fa26d3367). I don't know exactly what that is, but they have their API subscription price listed and it's expensive. Using IMDB APi wasn't an option anymore. Luckily, I found an alternative called [The Movie Database (TMDB) API](https://www.themoviedb.org/). Their API is free to use for non-commercial purposes, but you do need to attribute them as the source of the data and/or images. According to their official website, you can place the attribution within your application's "About" or "Credits" section. My movie review posts consist of two sections: the movie information section (title, release year, genres, director, cast, overview) and my take on the movie section. The data in the information section is fetched from the TMDB API using IMDB id as an identifier. You can get this id in the url when visitng the movie's page on IMDB. ![18Ã—2 Beyond Youthful Days' IMDB page](/content/programming/how-i-made-this-blog/image-1.png "18x2 Beyond Youthful Days' IMDB page") Using the IMDB id as an identifier, you can get the corresponding movie data from the TMDB API. Since the data in the movie information section is provided by TMDB, I only need to write my take on the movie as the body text and three pieces of data in the frontmatter â€” category, imdb id, and published date. ```md --- category: movie imdbId: tt31039829 publishedDate: 2025-02-26 --- _18Ã—2 Beyond Youthful Days_ is a pretty good film. ``` Remember that we can preprocess data in Velite before using it in our application. In my case, before using the data, I first fetch the corresponding movie data from TMDB using the IMDd id provided in each post. Then, I merge the data from the API with the data from the frontmatter and finally use it. ## Music Chart I created the Chart section mainly for fun and experimentation. Before bulding this blog, I believe I saw something similar on someone else's blog, but I couldn't remember exactly whose. I built the [Chart](https://mfaisal.xyz/chart) section because I was curious about how to implement it. To fetch top tracks data from [Spotify API](https://developer.spotify.com/documentation/web-api), you just need to make a request to the `https://api.spotify.com/v1/me/top/tracks` endpoint. The available optional query parameters for this endpoint are: 1. `time_range`: Over what time frame the affinities are computed. Valid values: `long_term` (calculated from ~1 year of data and including all new data as it becomes available), `medium_term` (approximately last 6 months), `short_term` (approximately last 4 weeks). Default: `medium_term` 2. `limit`: The maximum number of items to return. Default: `20`. Minimum: `1`. Maximum: `50`. 3. `offset`: The index of the first item to return. Default: `0` (the first item). I only needed to fetch the first top 10 tracks and I wanted to make it daily updated. In my case, the endpoint and its query parameters would be: ```{ts} https://api.spotify.com/v1/me/top/tracks?time_range=short_term&limit=10 ``` To automatically update the data daily, I used [Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR)](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/guides/incremental-static-regeneration). By using this, NextJS caches my data. To update the data daily, I revalidate the cache using time-based revalidation. ```tsx import { getTopTracks } from "../../../lib/spotify"; import Image from "next/image"; import type { Metadata } from "next"; export const metadata: Metadata = { title: "Chart | Faisal M.", description: "My current Spotify heavy rotation. Updated daily.", }; // Provide your time in second. export const revalidate = 86400; export default async function Chart() { const { tracks } = await getTopTracks(); return ( // My rendered page/component with the data ) } ``` The way this updates is honestly problematic because it's not precise. It will be updated on the first request after the `revalidate` interval (every 24h). Because of this, the cache might revalidate at unexpected times if the page is rarely visited. I plan to change the way I updated the Chart section daily. I need a solution that gives me control over when revalidation happens. For now, I'm okay with how it works. ## Inspiration While building this blog, I drew inspiration from existing websites created by awesome figures. Web Development in 2025: Trends, Challenges, and Opportunities

The field of web development is evolving at a breakneck pace, and 2025 is no exception. With emerging technologies, changing user behaviors, and new frameworks shaping the industry, developers must stay ahead of the curve.

The field of web development is evolving at a breakneck pace, and 2025 is no exception. With emerging technologies, changing user behaviors, and new frameworks shaping the industry, developers must stay ahead of the curve. In this article, weâ€™ll explore the key trends, challenges, and opportunities in web development for 2025.

## Key Trends in Web Development

### 1. AI-Powered Development

Artificial intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing web development. From AI-generated code to advanced chatbots and personalized user experiences, AI tools are helping developers work smarter. GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT-powered coding assistants, and automated UI/UX design tools are reducing development time and enhancing productivity.

### 2. Web3 and Decentralization

Web3 is becoming more mainstream, with blockchain-based applications growing in popularity. Decentralized applications (dApps) and smart contracts are creating a shift from traditional web development models to more secure and transparent systems. Developers who understand blockchain technology will be in high demand.

### 3. Low-Code and No-Code Platforms

The rise of low-code and no-code platforms like Webflow, Bubble, and Wix Studio is democratizing web development. These tools allow non-developers to create websites and apps with minimal coding knowledge. While this may reduce demand for basic coding jobs, it also opens new opportunities for developers to build advanced custom solutions.

### 4. Enhanced Web Performance and Speed

With Googleâ€™s Core Web Vitals still playing a crucial role in search rankings, website performance remains a top priority. Techniques like server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation (SSG), and edge computing are gaining traction to ensure lightning-fast web experiences.

### 5. Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) and Mobile-First Design

PWAs continue to bridge the gap between web and mobile applications. With better offline capabilities, push notifications, and fast loading speeds, PWAs are a viable alternative to native mobile apps. Additionally, mobile-first design remains essential, with mobile internet usage dominating over desktop.

### 6. Cybersecurity and Privacy-First Development

Data breaches and cyber threats are on the rise, making security a top concern in web development. Developers are increasingly adopting zero-trust security models, end-to-end encryption, and stricter compliance with data privacy regulations such as GDPR and CCPA.

## Challenges Facing Web Developers

### 1. Keeping Up with Rapid Technological Changes

New frameworks, libraries, and best practices emerge constantly, making it challenging for developers to stay updated. Continuous learning and adaptability are key to staying relevant in the industry.

### 2. Balancing Speed and Security

While fast-loading websites improve user experience and SEO rankings, security measures can sometimes slow things down. Striking a balance between performance and robust security is a major challenge.

### 3. Accessibility and Inclusivity

Web accessibility remains a critical yet often overlooked aspect of development. Ensuring that websites are usable for people with disabilities through proper semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, and keyboard navigation support is a growing priority.

### 4. Competition from AI and No-Code Tools

As AI and no-code tools become more sophisticated, traditional web developers face increased competition. To stay ahead, developers need to focus on custom solutions, problem-solving skills, and deeper technical expertise beyond drag-and-drop interfaces.

## Opportunities for Web Developers in 2025

### 1. Specializing in Niche Technologies

Developers who specialize in AI, Web3, cybersecurity, or accessibility will have a competitive edge. Mastering technologies like Next.js, Rust, or smart contract development can open new career paths.

### 2. Freelancing and Remote Work

With more companies embracing remote work, freelance web development opportunities continue to grow. Platforms like Upwork, Toptal, and Fiverr offer developers a way to work with global clients on flexible schedules.

### 3. Building Developer-Centric Products

Thereâ€™s a growing demand for developer tools, frameworks, and automation software. Creating open-source libraries, plugins, or SaaS products tailored to developers can be a lucrative venture.

### 4. Ethical and Sustainable Web Development

Sustainability in tech is gaining attention, with a focus on energy-efficient websites and eco-friendly hosting solutions. Developers who adopt sustainable coding practices and advocate for greener web technologies will be in high demand.

## Conclusion

Web development in 2025 is both exciting and challenging. The rise of AI, Web3, and low-code platforms is transforming the industry, while new security concerns and accessibility requirements demand more responsible coding practices. By staying adaptable, continuously learning, and specializing in emerging fields, developers can seize the many opportunities the future holds.
The Mystery of Time: A Journey Through Science and Philosophy

Time remains one of the most profound and perplexing mysteries in human understanding. While we experience time flowing forward, science and philosophy suggest that its nature may be far more complex than our daily perception.

Time remains one of the most profound and perplexing mysteries in human understanding. While we experience time flowing forward, science and philosophy suggest that its nature may be far more complex than our daily perception. In this article, we explore the scientific and philosophical aspects of time, shedding light on its enigmatic qualities.

## The Scientific Perspective on Time

### 1. Time in Physics: The Fourth Dimension

In Einsteinâ€™s theory of relativity, time is not an independent entity but rather a dimension interwoven with space, forming the fabric of spacetime ([source](https://www.nasa.gov/feature/the-theory-of-relativity-explained)). The passage of time is relative, meaning it can slow down or speed up depending on gravity and velocity. This concept is evidenced by time dilation, where astronauts moving at high speeds experience time more slowly than those on Earth.

### 2. The Arrow of Time and Entropy

One of the most intriguing questions in physics is why time moves forward and not backward. The second law of thermodynamics states that entropy, or disorder, always increases in a closed system ([source](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-arrow-of-time/)). This increase in entropy gives rise to the so-called arrow of time, defining a clear past, present, and future.

### 3. Quantum Mechanics and the Illusion of Time

Quantum mechanics challenges our classical view of time. Some interpretations suggest that time is an emergent property rather than a fundamental aspect of reality. The Wheeler-DeWitt equation, for instance, describes the universe in a way that does not explicitly involve time ([source](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41567-018-0078-7)). This raises the possibility that time, as we perceive it, may be an illusion.

## The Philosophical Perspective on Time

### 1. Presentism vs. Eternalism

Philosophers have long debated whether time is objectively real or a mere construct of human perception. Presentists argue that only the present moment exists, while eternalists claim that past, present, and future all exist simultaneously, much like the frames of a film strip ([source](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/time/)).

### 2. Time and Human Consciousness

Time perception is closely tied to human consciousness. Neuroscientific research suggests that our brains construct a sense of time through memory and prediction, rather than experiencing an objective flow of time ([source](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364661319300995)). This suggests that our experience of time may be subjective and influenced by psychological factors.

### 3. Time Travel: Science Fiction or Reality?

Time travel has fascinated humans for centuries, appearing in literature and films. While traveling to the future is theoretically possible through relativistic speeds, backward time travel remains speculative. Some physicists propose that wormholes or closed timelike curves might allow for backward time travel, though such ideas remain highly theoretical ([source](https://www.space.com/time-travel-theories.html)).

## Conclusion

The mystery of time continues to puzzle scientists and philosophers alike. Whether time is a fundamental aspect of reality or merely an emergent phenomenon, its implications touch every aspect of our existence. As our understanding of the universe deepens, we may one day unravel the true nature of time and its role in the cosmos.

The mystery of time continues to puzzle scientists and philosophers alike. Whether time is a fundamental aspect of reality or merely an emergent phenomenon, its implications touch every aspect of our existence. As our understanding of the universe deepens, we may one day unravel the true nature of time and its role in the cosmos.

Hirokazu Koreedaâ€™s _Our Little Sister_ (_Umimachi Diary_) is a beautifully tender and understated film that explores family, forgiveness, and quiet resilience. Unlike heavy melodramatic family dramas, Koreeda takes a naturalistic, almost meditative approach, allowing emotions to simmer beneath the surface rather than explode outright.

The film follows three sisters who take in their teenage half-sister after their estranged fatherâ€™s death. What makes it so poignant is how it captures the complexity of familial bondsâ€”not through grand conflicts but through everyday moments: cooking together, walking under cherry blossoms, sharing silent grief. The way the characters navigate their relationships, particularly their feelings toward the father who abandoned them, feels deeply human.

Koreeda excels at showing love in the small, unspoken gestures rather than dramatic dialogue. Thereâ€™s a quiet melancholy in how each character carries emotional wounds, yet thereâ€™s also warmth in the way they slowly find healing through togetherness. The seaside town setting adds to this nostalgic, almost dreamlike feeling, making the film feel like a collection of precious memories.

Overall, _Our Little Sister_ isnâ€™t a film that overwhelms you with emotions all at onceâ€”it lingers, gently reshaping your thoughts about family, regret, and the beauty of small moments. Itâ€™s a film that doesnâ€™t just tell a story but invites you to _live_ with its characters for a while.

Do you enjoy Koreedaâ€™s storytelling style, or do you prefer more emotionally intense narratives?

_18Ã—2 Beyond Youthful Days_ is a deeply melancholic film that explores love, time, and unfulfilled dreams through a delicate yet heartbreaking narrative. What sets it apart from similar romantic dramas is its quiet, almost understated approach to emotionsâ€”thereâ€™s no excessive melodrama, just a lingering sense of longing and inevitability.

The way the story unfolds, with its parallel timelines and the slow unraveling of the female protagonistâ€™s fate, makes the film more poignant. Unlike _La La Land_, where dreams take precedence over love, _18Ã—2_ presents a love story that is cut short not by choice but by circumstances beyond control. The protagonistâ€™s illness adds a layer of sorrow, especially when she holds onto the dream of traveling with her loved oneâ€”a dream that remains tragically unfulfilled.

The cinematography and music amplify the filmâ€™s wistful atmosphere, making it feel like a fading memory. Thereâ€™s a strong theme of nostalgia, where even fleeting happiness is tinged with sadness because we know it wonâ€™t last. That sense of impermanence lingers long after the credits roll.

Itâ€™s the kind of film that, rather than making you cry in the moment, slowly sinks into your mind, changing the way you see love, time, and regrets. I can see why it left a strong impression on you. Did any particular scene or moment stand out the most for you?

Hirokazu Koreedaâ€™s _Still Walking_ (_Aruitemo Aruitemo_) is one of the most profoundly subtle yet emotionally resonant family dramas Iâ€™ve ever seen. Itâ€™s a film that doesnâ€™t rely on big dramatic confrontations or plot twists; instead, it captures the quiet tensions, unspoken regrets, and unhealed wounds that exist within familiesâ€”especially between parents and their grown children.

The story unfolds over the course of a single day as the Yokoyama family gathers to commemorate the death of the eldest son, Junpei. What makes _Still Walking_ so impactful is how naturalistic and painfully real its dynamics feel. The aging parents, especially the father, harbor quiet disappointments in their surviving son, Ryota, who never lived up to their expectations. Thereâ€™s no explosive argument, just subtle passive-aggression, lingering resentment, and words left unsaidâ€”things that many families experience but rarely acknowledge out loud.

Koreedaâ€™s attention to small, everyday details is what makes the film feel so authentic. The way food is prepared, the awkward silences at the dinner table, the offhanded yet hurtful remarks that cut deepâ€”these moments feel like fragments of real life rather than scripted scenes. The film also carries a strong undercurrent of inevitability; time moves forward, regrets remain, and relationships donâ€™t always heal in the way we wish they would.

Despite its melancholic themes, _Still Walking_ isnâ€™t overly bleak. Thereâ€™s warmth, humor, and love, even if itâ€™s imperfectly expressed. Itâ€™s a film that lingers long after watching, making you reflect on your own family relationships, the things left unsaid, and the fleeting nature of time.

Itâ€™s one of Koreedaâ€™s best works, in my opinion. Did any scene or line in particular stand out to you?
